Application_Facts: Ms. Tajdini left the U.S. in 1996, lived in Iran until 2004, did not maintain U.S. residency requirements, fled Iran due to persecution fears, applied for refugee protection in Canada
Claimant_Status: Applicant for refugee status in Canada
Residency_Compliance: Failed to meet U.S. residency maintenance requirements
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review initiated by the Minister challenging Board's decision
Evidence_Used: Documentation of travel and residence history
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No evidence that Ms. Tajdini engaged in asylum shopping
Credibility_Assessment: The Board found Ms. Tajdini credible
Decision_Outcome: Board determined Ms. Tajdini lost U.S. permanent resident status and was eligible for refugee determination
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board’s decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Exclusion under Article 1E of the Refugee Convention
Decision_Rationale: Ms. Tajdini abandoned her U.S. permanent residency; no indication of asylum shopping; decision supported by evidence

Dispute_Type: Patent infringement dispute between brand-name and generic pharmaceutical companies
Legal_Issue: Whether Novopharm's product infringes claims 1, 41, or 78 of the '852 patent
Governing_Law: Patent Act (Canada), principles of purposive construction
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies were analyzed regarding drug release profiles and prior art
Burden_of_Proof: On the plaintiff (Janssen-Ortho) to prove infringement
Credibility_Factor: Weight given to expert evidence based on consistency with prior art and scientific plausibility
Legal_Rule: Patent claims must be interpreted through purposive construction considering the knowledge of a person skilled in the art (PSIA)
Standard_of_Review: Objective interpretation of patent claims in light of the specification and common general knowledge
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of claims 1, 41, and 78 of the '852 patent relating to sustained-ascending release of methylphenidate
Key_Evidence_Considered: Expert testimony on drug release mechanisms, comparison with Ritalin SR, prior art formulations
Legal_Framework: Purposive construction of patent claims, Federal Courts Act
Defendant_Response: Novopharm argued its product does not release methylphenidate in a sustained-ascending manner as required by the patent
Evidence_Type: Scientific expert reports, pharmacokinetic data, prior art patents
Remedy_Requested: Injunction and other remedies for patent infringement
Outcome: Application dismissed; Novopharm's product found not to infringe the '852 patent

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing False Testimony in Refugee Proceedings.
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Sections 96 and 97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants provided conflicting original and amended narratives; explanations for discrepancies were deemed unreasonable; insufficient efforts to seek state protection in Hungary
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Roma individuals claiming persecution in Hungary
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Inaccurate disclosure of key incidents and false testimony
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Credibility assessment based on inconsistent narratives
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Refugee claim under Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Original and Amended Narratives, hearing observations, evidence of attempts to access Hungarian state protection
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide key details (e.g., teacher’s name), whispering during hearings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicants not credible due to inconsistencies and lack of reasonable explanation
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review; decision upheld as reasonable
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of negative credibility finding and recognition of refugee status
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution; credibility central to assessment
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credibility undermined by false testimony; adequate state protection available in Hungary

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Impact of misrepresentation on credibility and refugee claim
Crimes.Outcome: Refugee claim denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found lack of credibility due to narrative discrepancies and reliance on template stories

Crimes.Legal_Provision: Definition of Convention refugee requiring well-founded fear of persecution
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Ethnic persecution as Roma in Hungary
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility and adequacy of state protection in Hungary
Crimes.Application_Error: Submission of inaccurate PIFs due to counsel incompetence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable basis for credibility and risk assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: N/A – court found evidence was properly assessed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Well-founded fear of persecution; burden on applicant to prove risk
Crimes.Application_Factor: Amendment of narratives and failure to explain initial inaccuracies
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of inaccurate PIFs and template-based narratives

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obstruction of Justice (alleged but not proven)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether delay in correcting false narratives constituted obstruction or procedural unfairness

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Obstruction requires active interference with legal process

Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, principles of natural justice
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicants attributed inaccuracies to counsel incompetence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, hearing transcripts, judicial review submissions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn RPD decision based on procedural unfairness

Crimes.Dispute_Type: False statements in sworn immigration forms
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether signing false PIFs constitutes perjury
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian law on perjury and immigration declarations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicants signed declarations of truth despite later admitting falsehoods

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Contradiction between signed declarations and later admissions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Perjury involves knowingly making false statements under oath

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed ignorance due to language and counsel issues

Crimes.Crime_Name: Breach of Duty of Fairness in Refugee Claims
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged procedural unfairness due to counsel incompetence
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether RPD's process breached duty of fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Principles of procedural fairness under Canadian administrative law

Legal_Issue: Whether Nidek's EC-5000 apparatus infringes VISX's patents for corneal surgery devices
Governing_Law: Patent law, specifically relating to the scope and construction of patent claims
Evidence_Assessment: Comparison of the EC-5000's technical features with the claims in VISX's patents
Burden_of_Proof: On VISX to prove infringement by a preponderance of evidence
Credibility_Factor: Court's interpretation of patent claims and technical functionality of the device
Legal_Rule: Infringement occurs when a device falls within the scope of a patent's claims; claim construction is a legal matter, infringement is a mixed question of fact and law
Standard_of_Review: De novo for claim construction, clear error for factual findings
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of three Canadian patents related to ophthalmological surgery devices
Outcome_on_Merits: Action dismissed; patents valid but not infringed
Key_Evidence_Considered: Technical design of EC-5000, including absence of anterior surface ablation, use of iris diaphragm/variable slit, lack of topography-display unit
Defendant_Response: EC-5000 does not meet the claimed elements of VISX's patents
Evidence_Type: Technical documentation, patent claims, device specifications
Remedy_Requested: Not specified, likely injunctive relief and damages
Legal_Provision: Relevant provisions of the Canadian Patent Act
Authority: Federal Court (implied from context of Canadian patent litigation)

Legal_Issue: Was the duty of fairness breached by failing to disclose the substance of interviews with Faduma and Abdiqani to the Applicant?
Governing_Law: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Outcome: The application for judicial review was dismissed; no breach of fairness was found.
Credibility_Assessment: Credibility issues due to inconsistent statements and discrepancies with relatives' accounts
Evidence_Type: Inconsistencies in the Applicant's statements, discrepancies with Faduma and Abdiqani's accounts, interview records
Legal_Provision: subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant had opportunity to respond to all concerns used in decision; undisclosed information did not influence outcome
Application_Error: Failure to disclose parts of interviews, but only non-relied-upon information was withheld
Evidence_Ignored: Parts of Faduma's interview not relied upon in decision
Legal_Standard: Duty of fairness requires applicant be given opportunity to respond to concerns
Application_Factor: Credibility concerns based on inconsistencies in own statements and third-party accounts

Crime_Name: Administrative Error in Visa Application Process
Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer correctly applied s. 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations in assessing Mr. Marr's educational credentials
Governing_Law: Section 78(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Outcome: The officer erred by failing to consider special circumstances under s. 78(4); decision set aside and application remitted for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Educational credential, duration of study, information on Scotland’s education system
Legal_Provision: s. 78(4), Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient points awarded due to misapplication of regulations regarding educational credentials
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer failed to consider special circumstances such as shorter education system in Scotland
Decision_Maker: Visa officer, later reviewed by Federal Court
Application_Error: Incorrect point allocation (15 instead of 20) for educational credential
Evidence_Ignored: Potential relevance of Scotland’s shorter post-secondary education system
Application_Factor: Two-year post-secondary credential with 13 years of study (not meeting 14-year threshold)
Decision_Outcome: Application refused initially; decision quashed and remitted for re-evaluation

Legal_Issue: Whether the registrant proved use of the VISIBLE YOUTH trademark during the relevant period
Evidence_Assessment: Initial finding of insufficient evidence; new affidavits and exhibits later demonstrated sufficient use
Burden_of_Proof: Registrant must show prima facie evidence of use
Credibility_Factor: Bona fide sale sufficient to establish use
Legal_Rule: A single bona fide sale constitutes use under section 45 of the Trade-marks Act
Outcome_on_Merits: Registration upheld due to proof of use prior to assignment in August 2001
Key_Evidence_Considered: Sales records, invoices, product images bearing the mark
Defendant_Response: Presented new affidavits and exhibits demonstrating use
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (invoices, sales records, product images)

Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's analysis of the child's best interests was reasonable under s. 25(1) of the IRPA

Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of child's best interests, living conditions in Brazil, adequacy of amenities
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Legal_Rule: Best interests of the child must be a primary consideration in H&C decisions under s. 25(1) IRPA
Grounds_for_Claim: Inadequate consideration of the child's best interests in H&C assessment
Outcome_on_Merits: Remitted for reconsideration by a different officer
Key_Evidence_Considered: Child’s ties to Canada, potential impact of removal on child, social and economic conditions in Brazil
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)
Defendant_Response: Refused inland permanent residence application based on insufficient H&C grounds
